occurrences.text: see this in our society today, and it's the enemy of contentment. And if I'm seeking to learn to be content, if I'm desiring to learn what Paul learned, what he references here in the book of Philippians, then I must be aware of what the enemy of contentment is. Listen, we live in a society that bombards us with advertisements, the marketing industry on telling you what you need and why you need it, right? Don't we? I mean, there are things that you purchase that you never even thought you needed, but you saw some kind of something and it's like, man, I guess I do need that. I've never been able to operate without that. I mean, isn't that amazing? And that's what the marketing industry, that's what they do, that's why they exist. Look at Jeremiah 6 and verse 13. For from the least of them, even unto the greatest of them, every one is given to covetousness. And from the prophet, even unto the priest, every one dealeth falsely. That is a sad indictment on the children of Israel, is it not? Judah, terrible indictment. Every one of them, from the least, even to the greatest, every one of them is given to covetousness, and every one of them, from the prophet, even unto the priest, dealeth falsely. This morning, this evening, whatever it is, this evening, our society is geared to cause us to be covetous.
